thread.title: Freedom boys soccer gets needed test, but pays high price against Liberty
thread.title_full: Freedom boys soccer gets needed test, but pays high price against Liberty

title: Freedom boys soccer gets needed test, but pays high price against Liberty
text:
There are plenty of lessons for Freedom High School’s boys soccer team to gain from its loss to rival Liberty . 
The price tag for those lessons, however, may have been too high. 
The Patriots fell to the Hurricanes 2-1 on Thursday night in an Eastern Pennsylvania Conference Steel Division game at Bethlehem Area School District Stadium. 
Big picture: Freedom (9-4 overall, 9-2 EPC) is still in good shape regarding the division standings and playoff positioning, but an injury to senior forward Mezen Abdalla cast a cloud over the team on Thursday. 
Abdalla, Freedom’s second leading scorer, was carried off the field with an apparent leg injury in the second half and would need further evaluation, according to coach Michael O’Connell. 
During the first half, the Patriots often seemed the more dangerous team compared to Liberty (10-1, 8-1), the area’s No. 2 team according to lehighvalleylive. 
“This was the type of game that they needed, kind of as a measuring stick, to see where they’re at,” O’Connell said. “Give Liberty a lot of credit, they’ve got a great record, they’re at the top of the district right now, they’re playing well. Our challenge was to see where we stood against that.” 
Freedom stood on even ground with its rival for about 65 minutes, before Hurricanes junior Abe Meral scored his second goal of the game to provide the decisive strike. 
RELATED : Liberty boys soccer's Abe Meral makes his coach look good in win over Freedom 
It left the Patriots lamenting missed opportunities. 
Abdalla knocked a breakaway opportunity over the crossbar 20 minutes into the first half and, six minutes later, had his sliding stab of a Steven Riad flick stopped by Liberty goalkeeper Tony Silva. 
Riad neatly put away a 1-on-1 opportunity early in the second half, but rest of the Patriots’ chances and half-chances didn’t really stress the Liberty defense. 
“There’s a little bit of a composure issue,” O’Connell said. “I think guys were in spots where they had to put the ball away, or at least put it on frame and see if the keeper could make a good save, or if there’d be a rebound opportunity. We just put too many balls wide or over the top.” 
The Patriots were effective at limiting the amount of possession that the Hurricanes had, but sharper decisions in the center of the field would have halted Liberty’s ability to counter, according to the coach. 
“Just understanding that moment and the different decisions you can make, I think will be big moving forward,” O’Connell said. 
Of course, the tests ahead will be more challenging if the team is without Abdalla, one of its senior leaders. 
“It’s an opportunity for guys to step up,” O’Connell said. “There are certainly guys that are on the bench, so we’ll see what they do.”
